author: Jordan Fabian
title: Obama mourns passing of former Rep. Louis Stokes
text: Obama mourns passing of former Rep. Louis Stokes By Jordan Fabian - 08/19/15 01:16 PM EDT President Obama on Wednesday mourned the passing of former Rep. Louis Stokes, the first black congressman elected from Ohio. “Lou leaves behind an indelible legacy in the countless generations of young leaders that he inspired, and he will be sorely missed,” the president said in a statement. ADVERTISEMENT Stokes died at his home Tuesday at the age of 90, one month after announcing he had been diagnosed with brain and lung cancer, The Associated Press reported . Stokes’s wife, Jay, was at his side when he passed away. The Ohio Democrat was a founding member of the Congressional Black Caucus. He rose to prominence leading a congressional committee that investigated the assassinations of former President John F. Kennedy and civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. He formed a powerful alliance with his younger brother, Carl, who was the first black mayor elected in a major U.S. city when he was elected mayor of Cleveland in 1968. “Lou believed deeply in fairness and the idea that every American should have the same opportunity to succeed,” Obama said. “Growing up in Depression-era Cleveland with his mother and brother Carl, Lou triumphed over hardship to become a passionate voice for those less fortunate.” Past: 1 day Clinton pulls plug on testy...
